importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Eurostar expects to start using the first six double-decker trains in 2031, marking a significant milestone in the rollout of new rail technology.
The announcement of the double-decker train order was published on this date, signaling a major shift in European rail operations and public transport innovation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline from 2025 to 2031 covers the certification, deployment, and operational use of the new double-decker trains, indicating a phased rollout over a six-year period.
The expansion plan announced in June 2024, including new routes and infrastructure investment, sets the foundation for this major train initiative.

keyTakeAways: Eurostar has ordered up to 50 double-decker trains from Alstom, with 30 already confirmed and 20 options available.
The new trains, named 'Celestia', will be 200 meters long and will allow for approximately 1,080 seats when run in tandem.
The first six trains are expected to enter service in 2031, with full deployment expected over several years.
The trains will be 4.33 meters high, just 16cm taller than current E320 models, and must pass a multi-country certification process for the Channel Tunnel.
A €2 billion deal includes a €80 million investment in upgrading the Temple Mills depot in London, currently the only UK depot capable of handling continental European trains.
The expansion supports Eurostar's goal to increase passenger numbers from 19.5 million to 30 million annually.
The move faces criticism due to the historical constraints of Britain’s rail infrastructure, including tunnels and overhead lines, which may not accommodate double-deckers.
The Temple Mills depot is under review by the Office of Rail and Road for potential access by rival operators, including Evolyn, Virgin, and Gemini Trains/Uber.
The double-decker trains represent the first time such service has operated through the Channel Tunnel, with the last such experiment dating back to 1949.

namedEntities.name: Eurostar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cross-Channel rail operator that runs high-speed services between London and Paris, and other European cities.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Eurostar is central to the article as the entity planning and implementing the first double-decker service through the Channel Tunnel.

namedEntities.name: Alstom
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A French multinational railway and aerospace company that manufactures trains and rail systems.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Alstom is the manufacturer of the new 'Celestia' double-decker trains ordered by Eurostar.

namedEntities.name: Celestia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A model of double-decker high-speed train developed by Alstom for Eurostar.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Celestia trains are the core of Eurostar's new fleet expansion, enabling increased capacity and comfort.

namedEntities.name: Channel Tunnel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A rail tunnel under the English Channel connecting France and the UK.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The trains are designed specifically to operate through the Channel Tunnel, marking a historic first in its use.

namedEntities.name: Temple Mills depot
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A London-based rail depot owned by the London St Pancras Highspeed organisation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The depot is essential for storing and maintaining the new double-decker trains and is currently exclusive to Eurostar.

namedEntities.name: Gwendoline Cazenave
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She has publicly championed the new double-decker initiative, emphasizing comfort and innovation.

namedEntities.name: Office of Rail and Road
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The UK regulatory body overseeing rail operations and infrastructure access.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Office is reviewing access to Temple Mills for both Eurostar and potential rival operators, raising competitive and regulatory issues.

namedEntities.name: Evolyn
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Spanish start-up aiming to establish cross-Channel rail services between London and France.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Evolyn is one of several rival companies seeking access to the Temple Mills depot, creating competition with Eurostar.

namedEntities.name: Virgin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A travel and transport company, led by Sir Richard Branson, proposing cross-Channel rail services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Virgin is a key competitor to Eurostar, seeking access to the Temple Mills depot to launch rival services.

namedEntities.name: Gemini Trains
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A train operator involved in a partnership with Uber to offer cross-Channel rail services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Gemini Trains, in partnership with Uber, is another potential rival aiming to access the Temple Mills depot.

namedEntities.name: Pete Waterman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A music producer and rail enthusiast who has expressed skepticism about double-decker trains on UK rail routes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provides expert opinion on the technical and logistical challenges of implementing double-deckers due to outdated infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: 19.5 million passengers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The number of passengers Eurostar carried in the previous year.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This figure establishes Eurostar's current scale and supports the strategic goal of increasing passenger numbers to 30 million.

namedEntities.name: 30 million passengers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The target passenger volume Eurostar aims to achieve by expanding its services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This growth target underpins the rationale for increasing train capacity via double-decker trains.

namedEntities.name: 200 meters
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The length of each double-decker train.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The train length is critical to understanding capacity and logistics, especially when two trains run together for a 400m service.

namedEntities.name: 4.33 meters
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The height of the new double-decker trains.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The height is slightly above current models and must pass strict tunnel and infrastructure safety requirements.

namedEntities.name: 16 cm
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The difference in height between new double-decker trains and current E320 models.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This small increase is significant due to safety and tunnel clearance constraints.

namedEntities.name: €2 billion
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The total value of the train order and associated investments.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This figure highlights the scale and financial commitment behind the double-decker expansion.

namedEntities.name: €80 million
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The amount allocated to develop the Temple Mills depot.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This investment underscores Eurostar's focus on infrastructure to support the new train fleet.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The year when a double-decker experiment occurred on British railways.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This historical context emphasizes the novelty of the current double-decker initiative in the UK.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eurostar has announced a major expansion plan to introduce double-decker high-speed trains through the Channel Tunnel for the first time, ordering up to 50 'Celestia' trains from Alstom under a €2 billion deal. The first six trains are expected to enter service in 2031, with the goal of increasing passenger capacity from 19.5 million to 30 million annually. A significant €80 million investment will go into upgrading the Temple Mills depot in London, the only UK facility capable of handling such trains. While Eurostar's leadership, including CEO Gwendoline Cazenave, highlights the initiative as a step toward enhanced passenger comfort, the move faces criticism from rail experts like Pete Waterman, who argue that Britain’s 200-year-old rail infrastructure is not built to accommodate double-deckers due to tunnel and overhead line constraints. The Office of Rail and Road is currently reviewing access to Temple Mills for rival operators such as Evolyn, Virgin, and Gemini Trains/Uber, signaling growing competition in cross-Channel rail services.
title: Eurostar orders first double-decker trains
